Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Modified Ligation Procedure and Stapled Haemorrhoidectomy for Symptomatic Haemorrhoids

Trial_Design.evidence: This single-centre, randomised, single-blind trial was conducted at Putuo Hospital, Shanghai, from May 2018 to September 2021.

Participants.evidence: Patients aged 18–80 years with symptomatic second- to fourth-degree haemorrhoids were randomised 1:1 to MLPPH or SH.

Intervention.evidence: Patients aged 18–80 years with symptomatic second- to fourth-degree haemorrhoids were randomised 1:1 to MLPPH or SH.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of a modified ligation procedure for prolapsed haemorrhoids (MLPPH) versus stapled haemorrhoidectomy (SH) in patients with symptomatic haemorrhoids.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the 6-month cure rate.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by haemorrhoid grade using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to participants or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 133 patients were randomised (67 to MLPPH, 66 to SH).

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 133 patients were randomised (67 to MLPPH, 66 to SH).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 6-month cure rate was higher in the MLPPH group (90.6%) compared to the SH group (69.7%) (P = 0.003).
